title: Booth Wood Reservoir Walking Route

images.title: Alexander P Kapp / Booth Wood Reservoir
images.caption: Booth Wood Reservoir. Originally built by The Wakefield and District Board in 1971 now owned by Yorkshire Water

images.title: Barry Daniels / Booth Wood Reservoir
images.caption: In the distance the widest single span bridge in Europe - Scammonden Bridge

images.title: Booth Wood Reservoir Car Park by Stephen Armstrong, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Car Park and surrounding hills.

images.title: Alexander P Kapp / Booth Wood Reservoir, Plaque
images.caption: Plaque at the site detailing the opening by Sir William Goode in 1971.

images.title: Paul Anderson / Booth Wood Reservoir
images.caption: This is the over spill at the reservoir after days of heavy rain. The reservoir was built in 1971 at a cost of two million pounds to supply Wakefield with an extra 2,540,000 gallons of water a day.

images.title: Humphrey Bolton / Part of Booth Wood Reservoir, Rishworth
images.caption: Privy Clough enters from the right. The M62 motorway goes across the scene below the ridge.

description: This pretty reservoir in Ripponden has nice footpaths climbing above the water. You can park at the Booth Wood Reservoir car park at the eastern end of the water, off Oldham Road. Then follow the public footpath above the reservoir's northern side, taking you through some nice Calderdale countryside. The path runs west, passing Rishworth Lodge and then down to the water. You could continue west to visit Green Withens Reservoir and then climb to the wonderful viewpoint on Blackstone Edge. Booth Wood is located just to the south of Rishworth and Ripponden. To continue your waterside walking you can visit the nearby Scammonden Reservoir, Deanhead Reservoir, Ryburn Reservoir and Baitings Reservoir .
